supporting.text: Water is the most natural and essential hydration source for cats, as it aligns with their biological needs.

attacks.text: Water is the most natural and essential hydration source for cats, as it aligns with their biological needs.
Cats in the wild often obtain hydration from prey, which contains fluids other than water, suggesting their biological needs are not exclusively met by water.
Some cats may require electrolyte solutions or specialized fluids due to health conditions, making water alone insufficient for their hydration needs.
While wild cats obtain fluids from prey, domesticated cats often lack access to such prey, making water the most practical and essential hydration source.
Electrolyte solutions or specialized fluids are exceptions for medical conditions and do not negate the general rule that healthy cats should primarily drink water.
Even domesticated cats can be fed wet food, which provides additional hydration, reducing their reliance on water alone.
The existence of medical exceptions highlights that water alone is not universally sufficient, undermining the claim that cats should only drink water.

supporting.text: Other beverages like milk can cause digestive issues in cats, such as lactose intolerance, making water the safest option.

attacks.text: Other beverages like milk can cause digestive issues in cats, such as lactose intolerance, making water the safest option.

Cats can get all necessary hydration and nutrients from water and a balanced diet, without needing other beverages.
Even lactose-tolerant cats can develop other health issues from milk, such as obesity, due to high calorie content.

supporting.text: Cats have evolved to obtain most of their hydration from prey, which is primarily water-based, so water alone suffices.

attacks.text: Cats have evolved to obtain most of their hydration from prey, which is primarily water-based, so water alone suffices.

supporting.text: Specialized cat milk substitutes exist that are lactose-free and formulated for feline digestion, providing an alternative to water.

attacks.text: Specialized cat milk substitutes exist that are lactose-free and formulated for feline digestion, providing an alternative to water.

supporting.text: In certain medical conditions, veterinarians may recommend electrolyte solutions or broth to ensure hydration, not just water.

attacks.text: In certain medical conditions, veterinarians may recommend electrolyte solutions or broth to ensure hydration, not just water.

supporting.text: Some cats enjoy and benefit from small amounts of bone broth, which provides nutrients without harmful additives.
